document.docAuthor: Brown, Brian V., Amorim, Dalton De Souza & Kung, Giar-Ann
document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 173 (2)
document.masterDocTitle: New morphological characters for classifying Phoridae (Diptera) from the structure of the thorax

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New morphological characters for classifying Phoridae (Diptera) from the structure of the thorax
Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

subSubSection.paragraph: This family includes Sciadocerinae , which was until recently considered a separate family (Disney, 2001), and the Euphorida ( Brown, 2007 ).
1. Costa extends: (0) to vein M 1 , (1) to, or just past, vein R 4+5 ( Fig. 10A–F ).

Reduction of costal length has not been described in sufficient detail in the literature, although it has been used in some analyses. In the platypezids we examined, the thickened part of the costa extends to vein M 1 ( Fig. 10A ), whereas it is shortened to only slightly beyond R in
Ironomyia
( Fig. 10B ). In
Lonchoptera
and phorids ( Fig. 10C–F ), the costa extends only to vein R
4+ 5
in most species.
Cumming et al . (1995)
considered the costa of
Lonchoptera
to extend completely around the wing, i.e. a circumambient costal vein, but examination of a microscopic slide mount shows that the costa narrows considerably after R 4+5 ( Fig. 10C ). Genus
Opetia Meigen
has the costal thickening ending shortly after R 4+5 ( Chandler, 2001 ). If the cladogram in
Cumming et al . (1995)
is correct, with
Opetia
being the sister group to other Cyclorrhapha, character state 0 is the derived one at this level, and would be a synapomorphy of Platypezidae . More recent phylogenetic studies of the Diptera , however, such as
Wiegmann et al . (2011)
, show the Opetiidae within the Platypezoidea. This character varies greatly among more distant outgroups ( Sinclair & Cumming, 2006 ).

subSubSection.paragraph: 2. R 4+5 : (0) connected to costa at apex, (1) not connected to costa at apex ( Fig. 11A–D ).

Although many wing venation characters have been used to justify the Phoridae , this is the first time that interruption of the CuA vein has been noticed. The Platypezidae have the plesiomorphic condition seen in other cyclorrhaphan families ( Fig. 12A ). In some phorids CuA+CuP is even more strongly disconnected from its base.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 12 Character 3. CuA+CuP complete (0); CuA+CuP interrupted just distal to point of fusion of CuA and CuP (1). A,
Lindneromyia
. B,
Sciadocera
. C,
Megaselia
. D,
Trophithauma
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The reduction of the extension of R 4+5 is a recurrent feature among families of Diptera . In the Platypezoidea, the plesiomorphic condition is seen in the Platypezidae ( Fig. 13A ), Opetiidae , Ironomyiidae and Lonchopteridae ( Fig. 13B ). R 4+5 ending before the wing tip, within the superfamily, is a synapomorphy of Phoridae . A small reduction is seen in the Sciadocerinae genera ( Fig. 13C ), as well as in the fossil
Sciadophora ( Brown, 1992 )
. In
Chonocephalus
( Fig. 13D ), R 4+5 extends until just beyond the middle of the wing, as is also seen in some other genera ( Fig. 13E– H ), such as
Latiborophaga
and
Trophithauma
. Even more extreme reductions, which are not coded here, are seen in the Termitoxeniinae and in some metopinine genera.

In all platypezoid families except Phoridae , the katepisternum anterior margin is continuous with the anepisternum–proepimeron (e.g. Fig. 14A, B ). The anterior limit between katepisternum and anepisternum in all Phoridae , differing from other platypezoid families, is marked by a furrow (the suture itself ending more posteriorly). In sciadocerines and
Chonocephalus
( Fig. 14C ) there is a depression between both sclerites, but in termitoxeniines and other phorids ( Fig. 14D– F ), a well-characterized furrow can be seen along the line of the anapleural suture to the anterior margin of the thorax. The metopinines and some phorines have an additional modification, the furrow curving dorsally and ending almost at the level of the insertion of the forecoxa. This produces a distinctive concavity above the forefemur. In a group of higher phorines, including thaumatoxenines and hypocerines, a suture extends to the ventral margin and the katepisternum does not extend anteriorly.

subSubSection.paragraph: 7. R 1 reaching at least: (0) distal third of wing length, (1) distal half of wing length, (2) basal third of wing length ( Fig. 13A–H ).

The reduction of the radial veins has been noted by other authors, especially McAlpine & Martin (1966) . Most platypezid genera we examined, as well as
Opetia
and
Ironomyia
, have the plesiomorphic condition ( Fig. 13A ). Character state 1 refers to the stage found in the Sciadocerinae ( Fig. 13C ) and the fossil
Sciadophora
, while character state 2 is synapomorphic for the rest of the Phoridae (= Euphorida). The Lonchopteridae have extremely short R 1 ( Fig. 13B ), an apomorphic condition apparently derived independently from that seen in the euphorids ( Fig. 13D–H ).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 16 Character 8. Alular setae plain (0); alular setae feathered (1). A,
Ironomyia
. B,
Lonchoptera
. C,

. D,

. E,

.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ironomyia
( Fig. 16A ) and
Lonchoptera
( Fig. 16B ) show the plesiomorphic condition, with long, unfeathered setae.
